history.title: Text Adaptation & Engagement

data.def: A major conflict fought between the northern states (the Union) and the southern states (the Confederacy) in the United States from 1861 to 1865.
A major separation or disagreement that causes people, groups, or things to become strongly split apart.
Men, women, and children who were treated like property and forced to work without wages or rights, primarily in the Southern states before 1865.
A large farm or estate in the Southern states where cash crops like cotton were grown, relying on the forced labor of enslaved people.
The system of how a country manages its money, trade, and resources, including how goods are produced and consumed.
To formally withdraw or leave an existing country or organization to form a separate nation.
An extreme, sudden, or severe action or change, often taken in response to a serious situation.
The new country formed by the eleven southern states that chose to secede from the United States during the Civil War.
The name for the northern states, led by Abraham Lincoln, that fought to keep the United States together during the Civil War.
To keep something going, or to continue to support and uphold a certain state or system.

config.standards: CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.2: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

data.main: Differences Between the Northern and Southern States Before the Civil War

branches.title: Northern States (The Union)
items: Most states had made slavery illegal (outlawed it).
Believed owning another person was morally wrong.
Their goal was to keep the United States together (unity).

branches.title: Southern States (The Confederacy)
items: Their economy depended on enslaved people working on large farms (plantations).
Wanted to keep slavery to protect their way of life.
Decided to leave (secede) the United States.
Formed their own country called the Confederacy.

branches.title: Shared
items: Were part of the same country (the United States) before the war.
Fought against each other in the Civil War.
Had families who were ripped apart by the fighting.

config.standards: CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.2: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

items.text: I think the main idea of the whole text is that the Civil War was a fight over ________________ and that it finally ended ________________.
One key detail that supports this main idea is that the Southern states decided to secede, or leave, because ________________.
The text explains that the major cause of the war was ________________, and this supports the main idea because it created a huge division between ________________ and ________________.
Another important detail is that even President Lincoln’s family was divided when ________________, which shows that the main idea about ________________ is true.
After the war ended, the biggest change was ________________. This proves the main idea because the war resulted in ________________.
This detail shows that the war was not just about fighting, but also about the important goals of ________________ and ________________.

data.rubric:
| Criteria | Level 1 (Beginning) | Level 3 (Developing) | Level 5 (Mastery) |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **Content: Main Idea (RI.3.2)** | Student does not identify the main idea or provides an unrelated topic. | Student identifies a partial or simple main idea (e.g., "The war was sad"). | Student clearly and accurately determines the complex main idea (cause and outcome) of the text. |
| **Content: Supporting Details (RI.3.2)** | Student includes 0-1 unrelated or incorrect detail from the text. | Student recounts 2-3 key details but struggles to accurately explain how they support the main idea. | Student recounts 3+ specific, accurate key details from the text. |
| **Use of Scaffolds (RI.3.2)** | Student ignores the sentence starters or uses them incorrectly, resulting in confusing sentences. | Student uses 2-3 sentence starters to structure their answer, but the completion is sometimes incomplete or unclear. | Student successfully uses at least 4 provided sentence starters to clearly recount details and explain support. |
| **Mechanics (L.3.1, L.3.2)** | Contains multiple errors in capitalization, punctuation, and complete sentences, making the writing hard to follow. | Contains some errors in spelling or punctuation, but the writing is generally understandable. | Uses correct capitalization and punctuation; sentences are complete and easy to read.

config.standards: CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.2: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

data.question: What was the main reason the Civil War began?
data.answer: The Civil War began because the Northern states and Southern states disagreed strongly about slavery and who had the power to make laws about it.

data.question: How were the North and South different before the war?
data.answer: The South used enslaved people to work on large farms and believed their whole way of life depended on it. The North believed that owning another person was morally wrong and had outlawed slavery.

data.question: What were plantations in the South used for?
data.answer: Plantations were large farms where hundreds of enslaved people were forced to work. They mainly grew cash crops like cotton that made the owners very rich.

data.question: Why did southern states secede from the United States?
data.answer: Southern states worried that the national government would force them to end slavery. To protect their way of life, eleven states decided to secede, or leave, and form their own country called the Confederacy.

data.question: What was the biggest change that happened when the war ended?
data.answer: The biggest change was the end of slavery. The Thirteenth Amendment was added to the Constitution, making slavery illegal forever across the entire United States.

config.standards: CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.2: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

questions.question: What is the main idea of the first section of the text, "Two Countries, One Family"?
options: It explains why General Grant was generous to the defeated soldiers.
It describes the major causes that led to the start of the Civil War.
It tells about the challenges faced by freed people after the war.
It explains where Appomattox Court House is located.
questions.correctAnswer: It describes the major causes that led to the start of the Civil War.
questions.factCheck:
**Verified Correct Answer:** It describes the major causes that led to the start of the Civil War.

For a historical text titled "Two Countries, One Family" (referencing the North and South during the Civil War), the opening section must establish the context of the division. The main idea of the first section of a historical narrative is typically to set the stage, meaning it explains the fundamental tensions, disagreements (causes), and conditions that led to the conflict described in the rest of the text.

**Why other options are incorrect:**

*   **It explains why General Grant was generous to the defeated soldiers.** This is a detailed event related to the *conclusion* of the war (Appomattox), not the main idea of the introductory section explaining the conflict's origins.
*   **It tells about the challenges faced by freed people after the war.** This subject belongs to the post-war period (Reconstruction) and would appear in later sections dedicated to the war's consequences.
*   **It explains where Appomattox Court House is located.** This is a specific geographical detail about the *location of the surrender*, which is far too narrow and specific to serve as the main idea of the opening section explaining the causes of the entire conflict.

questions.question: According to the text, what was the most important cause that led to the division between the Northern and Southern states?
options: The argument over who would be president.
The differences about slavery and who had the power to make laws about it.
The fighting over who owned the most horses.
The need to rebuild cities and towns.
questions.correctAnswer: The differences about slavery and who had the power to make laws about it.
questions.factCheck:
**Verified Correct Answer:** The differences about slavery and who had the power to make laws about it.

The division between the Northern and Southern states leading up to the Civil War was fundamentally caused by the conflict over slavery. The South’s economy depended heavily on slave labor, while the North largely opposed slavery. This core disagreement led to continuous disputes over whether new territories would allow slavery and whether the Federal government (the U.S. Congress) had the power to restrict or abolish slavery—which is accurately summarized by the differences over slavery and who had the power to make laws about it.

**Why other options are incorrect:**

*   **The argument over who would be president.:** Arguments over presidential candidates were immediate triggers for secession (like the election of Abraham Lincoln in 1860), but they were not the underlying *cause* of the deep division itself.
*   **The fighting over who owned the most horses.:** This is historically irrelevant and played no role in the national division.
*   **The need to rebuild cities and towns.:** Rebuilding cities and towns (known as Reconstruction) happened *after* the war and the division ended. It was a result, not a cause, of the division.

questions.question: Why did the Southern states feel that slavery was necessary for their economy (their way of making money)?
options: They needed enslaved people to run the banks in the North.
They believed their entire way of life depended on forced labor on large farms called plantations.
They wanted to write a new rule called the Thirteenth Amendment.
They needed more soldiers for the Union army.
questions.correctAnswer: They believed their entire way of life depended on forced labor on large farms called plantations.
questions.factCheck:
**Verified Correct Answer:** They believed their entire way of life depended on forced labor on large farms called plantations.

The Southern economy was based primarily on cash crops—most notably cotton, but also tobacco and sugar—grown on large estates known as plantations. This agricultural system required massive amounts of manual labor and was only profitable because this labor (slavery) was unpaid. Southern political and economic leaders argued that abolishing slavery would immediately collapse their entire financial structure and destroy their social hierarchy, thus making forced labor absolutely necessary for their continued existence and prosperity.

**Why other options are incorrect:**

*   **They needed enslaved people to run the banks in the North.** This is factually incorrect. Slavery was concentrated in the South for agricultural labor. Northern banks were not operated by enslaved people.
*   **They wanted to write a new rule called the Thirteenth Amendment.** This is factually incorrect. The Thirteenth Amendment (ratified after the Civil War) officially abolished slavery in the United States. Southern states fought to preserve slavery, not abolish it.
*   **They needed more soldiers for the Union army.** This is factually incorrect. The Southern states formed the Confederacy and fought *against* the Union army. The primary role of enslaved people was agricultural labor, not military service for the North.

questions.question: What was the 'drastic step' that the Southern states took that truly started the Civil War?
options: They voted for a new president.
They outlawed farming in the North.
They decided to secede, or leave, the United States to form the Confederacy.
They signed a peace treaty in Virginia.
questions.correctAnswer: They decided to secede, or leave, the United States to form the Confederacy.
questions.factCheck:
**Verified Correct Answer:** They decided to secede, or leave, the United States to form the Confederacy.

The act of secession was the "drastic step" taken by the Southern states (starting with South Carolina in December 1860) that led directly to the formation of the Confederate States of America (the Confederacy). Secession was the definitive political action that fractured the Union and was immediately followed by military actions (such as the firing on Fort Sumter in April 1861), which are considered the military start of the war. For a 3rd-grade context, secession is the primary cause attributed to the Southern states starting the conflict.

**Why other options are incorrect:**

*   **They voted for a new president.** The election of Abraham Lincoln (a Republican who opposed the spread of slavery) triggered the secession crisis, but Lincoln was elected primarily by Northern votes. Secession, not voting for a president, was the decisive action taken by the Southern states that started the conflict.
*   **They outlawed farming in the North.** This is entirely false. The Civil War was not about outlawing farming; it was rooted in the issues of slavery, states' rights, and economic differences.
*   **They signed a peace treaty in Virginia.** This is the opposite of starting a war. A peace treaty (like the one signed at Appomattox Court House, Virginia) is used to end a conflict.

questions.question: The Union (North) fought to keep the country united. What was the main reason the Confederacy (South) fought?
options: To keep the Stars and Stripes flag.
To stop using cotton as a crop.
To be a new, independent country and maintain the system of slavery.
To elect General Grant as president.
questions.correctAnswer: To be a new, independent country and maintain the system of slavery.
questions.factCheck:
**Verified Correct Answer:** To be a new, independent country and maintain the system of slavery.

The Confederacy (the eleven states that seceded from the United States) fought the Civil War primarily to establish a new nation, the Confederate States of America. This desire for independence was driven almost entirely by the goal of protecting and maintaining the economic, political, and social institution of chattel slavery, which they felt was threatened by the growing anti-slavery movement in the North and the election of Abraham Lincoln.

**Why other options are incorrect:**

*   **To keep the Stars and Stripes flag.**
    *   Incorrect. The Confederacy rejected the authority of the United States and designed its own national flags (such as the Stars and Bars) to distinguish itself from the Union.
*   **To stop using cotton as a crop.**
    *   Incorrect. Cotton was the main cash crop of the South, and its massive production relied entirely on the forced labor of enslaved people. The South fought to *protect* the system that made the cotton economy possible.
*   **To elect General Grant as president.**
    *   Incorrect. General Ulysses S. Grant was the lead commander of the Union Army (the North). The Confederacy fought against Grant and the U.S. government he served.

reflections: The text says that the Civil War was 'a fight between brothers' and that President Lincoln's own family was divided. How does this detail help you understand the main idea that the war 'tore the United States apart'?

config.standards: CCSS.ELA-LITERACY.RI.3.2: Determine the main idea of a text; recount the key details and explain how they support the main idea.

materialsNeeded: Teacher Device and Projector (or interactive whiteboard)
objectives: Students Will Be Able To (SWBAT) determine the main idea of the core text, 'The Civil War,' using explicit textual evidence (CCSS.RI.3.2).
SWBAT recount at least two key details (slavery, plantations) that support the main idea of the text (CCSS.RI.3.2).
SWBAT define and use domain-specific vocabulary (Civil War, enslaved people, plantation) using the provided glossary.
data.essentialQuestion: What caused the biggest fight in American history, and why was it so difficult to stop?
data.hook:
Teacher says: 'Imagine you have a big team, and everyone agrees on the rules—until suddenly, half the team wants totally different rules! That’s what happened to the United States. We became two groups fighting each other.' 

Direct students' attention to the projector. Display the  [Visual Organizer](resource:17672846765411vgftshoe)

Teacher says: 'Look closely at this image. What do you notice? Does it look like people are working together or divided? This image represents the Civil War, where Americans fought Americans. Today, we are going to learn why this terrible division happened.' (2-3 minutes)
data.directInstruction:
MINI-LESSON: Determining Main Idea and Key Details (15 minutes)

**1. Vocabulary Preview (Multiple Means of Representation):**
Teacher says: 'Before we read, let’s look at some important words. I am displaying the [Glossary & Language Selection](resource:1767284670008ojdok8qsm).
*   **Civil War:** A war fought inside one country.
*   **Enslaved People:** People who are owned by others and forced to work without pay or freedom. This is cruel and wrong.
*   **Plantation:** Very large farms in the South where enslaved people were forced to work, especially growing cotton.'

**2. Close Reading and Modeling (Core Text):**
Teacher says: 'We are going to read 'The Civil War' using the [Text Adaptation & Engagement](resource:1767284601643dtsg5buju). Remember, our goal is to figure out the **Main Idea**—what the text is mostly about—and find the **Key Details** that prove it.'

*(Teacher reads the text aloud, pausing after the second paragraph.)*

Teacher says: 'The text says the Civil War was a big fight that broke the U.S. into two pieces. But what was the *main reason* for this fight? Let's check the second paragraph. I see the sentence: 'The main reason for this sad fight was slavery.'

**Modeling Main Idea:** 'If I had to put this into one sentence, the main idea of this section is: **The Civil War happened because the northern and southern states disagreed strongly about slavery and unity.'**

**3. Modeling Key Details (RI.3.2):**
Teacher says: 'Now, what details prove that slavery was the main reason? Let's keep reading.'
*(Teacher reads through the section on plantations and cotton.)*

Teacher says: 'I found two key details right away:
*   **Detail 1:** The South used enslaved people who worked on plantations.
*   **Detail 2:** The South believed their money/economy depended on keeping slavery.

**Check for Understanding (CFU):**
*   Teacher asks: 'Based on the text, what big problem caused the Civil War?' (Expected Student Response: Slavery/Disagreement about slavery.)
*   Teacher asks: 'Where did enslaved people work in the South, according to the text?' (Expected Student Response: On plantations.)
*   Teacher asks: 'How do these details (slavery, plantations) support the main idea that the states were divided?' (Expected Student Response: The South needed plantations/slavery to make money, but the North disagreed with owning people.)
data.guidedPractice:
GROUP ACTIVITY: Organizing Information (15 minutes)

**1. Introduction to the Organizer (Representation):**
Teacher divides students into small groups (3-4 students). Assign the [Visual Organizer](resource:17672846765411vgftshoe) digitally or distribute printed copies. This organizer has a center box (Main Idea) and surrounding boxes (Key Details).

**2. Collaborative Completion (Engagement & Expression):**
Teacher says: 'Working with your group, use the text we just read, [Text Adaptation & Engagement](resource:1767284601643dtsg5buju), to fill out your organizer. We already identified the main idea together, so write that in the center box.
*   **Center Box (Main Idea):** The Civil War was a fight between Americans caused primarily by the issue of slavery.

'Now, groups must locate and write down four specific Key Details that support this main idea in the outer boxes. Focus on concepts like *secession*, *plantation economy*, and the *division* itself. Encourage groups to reference the [Glossary & Language Selection](resource:1767284670008ojdok8qsm) if they get stuck on terminology.

**3. Share Out:**
Teacher facilitates a quick share-out, asking 2-3 groups to read one key detail they found. This ensures groups who struggled have accurate information before independent practice.
data.independentPractice:
INDIVIDUAL WORK: Summarizing the Text (10 minutes)

**1. Task Setup (Action & Expression):**
Teacher instructs students to synthesize their learning by writing a short summary explaining the main idea of the text and supporting it with key details. The summary should be 3-5 sentences long.

**2. Scaffolding Provided:**
Teacher says: 'To help you structure your summary, I want everyone to use the [Writing Scaffolds](resource:1767284685352d8511575j). These sentence starters will help you clearly state the main idea and link your evidence (key details) directly back to it.'

*   *(Example Scaffolds: 'The main idea of the text is _____. One important detail that supports this is _____. Another detail is that the South believed _____, which shows the division.')*

**3. Monitoring:**
Teacher circulates, ensuring students are using the scaffolds and accurately citing details derived from the [Visual Organizer](resource:17672846765411vgftshoe). (UDL: Providing differentiated means for students to express understanding.)
data.closure:
ASSESSMENT: Exit Ticket and Reflection (7 minutes)

Teacher says: 'Great job identifying the main reasons for the Civil War. Now, you will complete a quick quiz to show what you learned today.'

**1. Assessment:**
Students complete the [Exit Ticket](resource:1767284706647lbi334rck). This resource includes 5 multiple-choice questions focusing on RI.3.2 (identifying the main idea and supporting details like slavery/plantations) and 1 reflection prompt.

**2. Discussion:**
Collect/Review the Exit Tickets. Conclude with a brief restatement of the Essential Question: 'Why did the United States split apart and fight against itself?'

Teacher says: 'We learned that the major cause was slavery. We will look next time at how these differences led to battles and how the war finally ended.'

extensions.title: Creative Question Generation (UDL: Multiple Means of Action & Expression)
extensions.description: Students use the provided [FAQ Generator](resource:17672846923041x17qrpmj) tool. Based on the reading, students must generate three 'tough' questions about the causes of the war. They then research the answers using provided simplified sources or classroom materials. This challenges them to seek deeper understanding beyond the immediate text.

extensions.title: Geography of Division (UDL: Interdisciplinary Connection)
extensions.description: Provide a map of the United States in 1861. Students identify and label the Union States (North), the Confederacy States (South), and the Border States (those that allowed slavery but stayed in the Union, like Kentucky). They use color coding to visualize the geographical division that the text describes, linking the historical event to current geographical knowledge.

extensions.title: Character Perspective Drawings (UDL: Multiple Means of Engagement)
extensions.description: Students choose one key figure or group mentioned in the context (e.g., Abraham Lincoln, an enslaved person, a plantation owner, or a Union soldier). They create a drawing or digital storyboard depicting what that person might have felt or thought about the disagreement over slavery and division. Students must include one caption summarizing their character's perspective based on the text.
